page-0.title:
Scaling Down to Zero:
The Need to Reconsider Negative Emissions Technologies

text: Climate scientists agree: the earth is warming largely due to greenhouse gas emissions. Logically, the most important step is reducing emissions.  But one concern is dealing with historic emissions trapped in the atmosphere. (1/3)

In a race against the clock, climate governance is embracing a variety of geoengineering technologies to eliminate some of these emissions. However, given that these solutions aren’t being paired with meaningful fossil fuel reductions, they will most likely be used to justify continuing business-as-usual practices.
page-2.hoverText: Geoengineering: To make a large-scale effort to modify the earth or its environment, especially to counteract global warming

text: This project looks at the nuances of one of these technologies called Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage, or BECCS. So how does BECCS work?

'The idea is that, as it grows, biomass will continuously capture CO2 from the atmosphere. When the biomass is burned for energy, the waste CO2 will also be captured and stored underground, instead of being released back into the atmosphere. The assumption is that this will result in negative emission'(FOEI).
page-4.summary: Crops capture C02, crops are burned, and CO2 is stored underground

text: For example, rather than planting a diverse forest ecosystem, usually one single fast growing tree species is planted (referred to as monoculture plantations) which requires large amounts of land and high external inputs, including water and chemicals (1). Even more, BECCS has hardly been tested.
page-5.summary: There are many flaws to this logic

text: One of those is the Decatur ethanol refinery, owned by the largest agribusiness in the world, The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company. Although it’s supposedly ‘carbon negative’, meaning it reduces more carbon than it emits, the fact that it is powered by fossil fuels and uses corn (an energy-intensive crop) makes this doubtful (Big Bad Fix).
page-6.summary: Only a few plants currently exist worldwide

page-7.summary: Let's look at past CO2 emissions to understand BECCS' future role

page-8.text: One gigaton = one billion tons, measuring global emissions
page-8.annotation: Edison invents the central power station in 1882. At this time, global GHG emissions were nearing only 1 gigaton.

page-9.annotation: Emissions quickly rise. But not all are equitably produced; by 1970, the U.S. and U.K. were responsible for 75% of emissions worldwide.
page-9.hoverText: Given this stark statistic, the concept of 'Common But Differentiated Responsibility' emerged, recognizing the historical responsibility of industrialized countries for global environmental problems, and implying they take far-reaching measures in responding meaningfully to such problems (2).

page-10.annotation: Today global emissions have reached more than 35 gigatons per year, and are projected to continue.

page-11.annotation: This accumulation of emissions corresponds to a rise in temperature of 1.16°C (2°F). If we compare this rise to body temperature, a 2°F increase signals a problem.

page-12.annotation: Now let’s look forward to possible future scenarios.

page-13.annotation: Absent any changes, temperatures are set to rise to at least 39°F above pre-industrial levels. This is referred to as the baseline scenario.

page-14.annotation: If all current climate mitigation policies are enforced, the trajectory would look something like this: where temperatures might rise by about 37°F.

page-15.annotation: Finally, there are scenarios that lead us to stay below a 35°F rise, corresponding to 1.5°C and 2°C, this is the threshold that climate scientists agree will help us to avoid unpredictable climate reactions.

page-16.annotation: One reason to be concerned about BECCS in particular is because it is one of the major players in these pathways. In fact of the 116 scenarios that would most likely keep global temperatures below 1.5 degrees, BECCS is included in 80% of them.

text: One reason is the amount of resources BECCS would require. Let's look at how much land would be needed for the crop plantations and factories.
page-17.summary: So why should we be concerned about this?

text: See more critique or jump to conclusion?

Another concern regarding BECCS is the fact that many fossil fuel companies are backing this technology. One concerning practice is called Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR). The liquid CO2 (produced by BECCS) is used to extract oil from a site that otherwise would not produce additional oil. [statistic about how 40% of co2 from one beccs site is already being used for that.
Additionally, BECCS models often don't account for the entire carbon lifecycle, many of which are unacknowledged in BECCS models.
page-22.summary: BECCS is not a negative emitter

text: Because industrial agriculture is required for BECCS, many additional emissions are released. In fact, industrial agriculture accounts for one-third of all global greenhouse gas emissions.

Strategies like BECCS are not viable because they delay the necessity for an immediate and systemic reduction of fossil fuels by depending on the illusion of ‘offsetting’, or the idea that we can remove what we emit. However, it’s hard to believe we will eventually create an industrial-scale technology with no serious social or ecological ramifications.

But there are many other alternative pathways that don’t rely on risky interventions, and have existed for centuries. One example of this is community-based forest management. For example, the peasant food web is already able to feed 70% of the population while using less than 25% of natural resources. If we reject technologies like BECCS while phasing out fossil fuels, we will begin to see the abundance of solutions that lay within reach.
